The morning sun filtered through the dusty workshop windows of Geelong Electric Services, casting long shadows across the concrete floor where Stafford McKenzie crouched, his weathered hands working methodically through a tangle of copper wiring. At thirty-two, he had spent nearly half his life learning the language of electricity—understanding how current flows, where resistance builds, and why circuits sometimes fail without warning. There was something almost poetic about it, he thought, the way power moved invisibly through walls and brought life to dead spaces.

His apprenticeship had begun when he was barely seventeen, eager to escape the suffocating expectations of university that his parents had pressed upon him. While his classmates pursued degrees in business and engineering, Stafford found solace in the honest work of his hands. The smell of heated wire, the satisfying snap of a properly installed breaker, the gentle hum of a well-wired panel—these became the soundtrack of his adult life.

But lately, something had been missing. Perhaps it was the repetitive nature of residential work, or maybe the growing sense that his skills had plateaued. His supervisor, Jim Hartwell, a gruff man in his sixties who had been rewiring Geelong homes since the seventies, noticed Stafford's restlessness during their coffee breaks.

"You're getting that look again," Jim observed one Tuesday morning, stirring sugar into his instant coffee with a plastic spoon. "Same look my youngest had before he decided to become a bloody chef instead of taking over the family business."

Stafford glanced up from his work order, pen hovering over the clipboard. "What look?"

"Like you're somewhere else entirely. Like this—" Jim gestured around the cramped office with its peeling linoleum and fluorescent lights "—isn't enough anymore."

The comment stung because it carried truth. Stafford had been feeling increasingly disconnected from his work, going through the motions without the passion that once drove him to master every aspect of electrical installation. He completed jobs efficiently, customers praised his professionalism, but the spark—if he could forgive himself the pun—had dimmed considerably.

That afternoon, while replacing a faulty outlet in a weatherboard house on Aberdeen Street, Stafford found himself thinking about Jim's words. The homeowner, an elderly woman named Mrs. Chen, brought him tea and biscuits, chatting about her late husband who had also worked with his hands as a carpenter. She spoke with such warmth about how he had found joy in creating something beautiful and functional from raw materials.

"He used to say that every piece of wood had a story to tell," Mrs. Chen explained, settling into her favorite armchair while Stafford tested the new outlet. "You just had to listen carefully enough to hear it."

As he packed his tools and prepared to leave, Mrs. Chen handed him a small card. "My neighbor mentioned you might be interested in expanding your skills. There's an adult education center downtown that offers evening classes. All sorts of subjects—literature, history, even some technical courses that might complement your electrical work."

Stafford accepted the card politely, expecting to forget about it before he reached his van. But something about the woman's genuine concern, combined with his growing dissatisfaction, made him slip the card into his wallet instead of the trash.

The Geelong Community Learning Center occupied a converted Victorian mansion on Moorabool Street, its red brick facade softened by climbing ivy and the warm glow of windows that promised knowledge and possibility. Three days after his encounter with Mrs. Chen, Stafford found himself climbing the front steps, drawn by curiosity and a vague hope that perhaps expanding his mind might rekindle his passion for his craft.

The reception area buzzed with activity—students of all ages consulting bulletin boards, elderly couples discussing pottery classes, young mothers juggling toddlers while inquiring about computer courses. Stafford felt simultaneously out of place and oddly at home among these seekers of knowledge.

A cheerful woman behind the information desk handed him a course catalog thick with possibilities. "First time here? Wonderful! We have classes starting next week in everything from basic accounting to creative writing. What sort of thing interests you?"

Stafford flipped through the pages, his eyes scanning course descriptions that ranged from practical to purely intellectual. Automotive maintenance, small business management, photography, philosophy—the variety was overwhelming. Then, near the back of the catalog, he found something that made him pause: "Literature and Life: How Great Books Shape Our Understanding of the World."

The course description was modest but intriguing: "An exploration of classic and contemporary literature, designed for adult learners who want to discover how storytelling reflects and influences human experience. No previous English literature background required. Evening sessions accommodate working adults."

Something about the phrasing appealed to him. He had always been a reader, though his tastes ran more toward technical manuals and thriller novels than what might be considered serious literature. But the idea of understanding how stories worked, how writers managed to capture complex emotions and experiences in words, held unexpected appeal.

The woman at the desk noticed his interest. "That's one of our most popular courses. Dr. Morrison is an exceptional instructor—really knows how to make literature accessible without dumbing it down. The class is quite diverse, too. We've had everyone from retired teachers to trades people to busy parents."

Stafford found himself nodding, though he hadn't consciously made a decision. "How do I enroll?"

Twenty minutes later, he walked back to his van with a receipt for his first literature course, wondering what impulse had led him to commit to spending two evenings a week discussing books with strangers. The rational part of his mind questioned whether he would have time for homework and reading assignments on top of his regular work schedule. But a deeper part of him, the part that had been growing increasingly restless, felt genuinely excited for the first time in months.

The following Tuesday evening, Stafford arrived at the learning center fifteen minutes early, carrying a notebook and the course's first assigned reading—a collection of short stories that he had managed to work through over the weekend. The classroom was smaller than he had expected, arranged with desks in a rough circle rather than traditional rows. Slowly, other students filtered in: a woman in her fifties wearing scrubs who he guessed was a nurse, a young man with paint-stained fingers who might have been an artist, several people around his own age whose professions were less obvious.

At exactly seven o'clock, the instructor entered, and Stafford felt his carefully managed expectations shift dramatically.

Dr. Elizabeth Morrison was perhaps thirty-five, with dark hair pulled back in a practical ponytail and intelligent eyes that seemed to take in everything at once. She wore a simple blue dress and carried a leather satchel that looked well-used and well-loved. But it wasn't her appearance that caught Stafford off-guard—it was the way she moved through the space, the quiet confidence with which she arranged her materials, the genuine smile she offered to each student as she made eye contact around the room."Good evening, everyone," Dr. Morrison said, her voice carrying easily through the small classroom without seeming forced or theatrical. "I know some of you might be wondering what you've gotten yourselves into, especially if it's been a while since you've been in a classroom setting. I want to start by assuring you that this isn't going to be like any English class you might remember from school. We're not here to dissect literature until it's lifeless, or to hunt for hidden meanings that may or may not exist. We're here to explore how stories work, why they matter, and what they can teach us about being human."

She moved to the whiteboard and wrote a single question in neat handwriting: "What is a story?" Then she turned back to face the class, leaning against her desk with an expression that invited participation rather than demanded it. "I'd like to hear from each of you—just briefly—about a story that has stayed with you. It doesn't have to be from a book. It could be something someone told you, a family legend, even something you experienced yourself. What made it memorable?"

The silence that followed wasn't uncomfortable, but rather expectant. Stafford found himself thinking not about books he had read, but about the stories his grandfather used to tell about working on the railways, tales filled with larger-than-life characters and near-disasters avoided through quick thinking and teamwork. Those stories had shaped his understanding of honest work and the dignity that came from doing a job well, even when nobody was watching.

The woman in scrubs spoke first, her voice soft but clear. "My grandmother used to tell me stories about growing up during the Depression. They weren't particularly dramatic stories—mostly about making do with very little, finding ways to celebrate small victories. But they taught me more about resilience than any self-help book ever could. Even now, when I'm having a difficult day at the hospital, I remember her stories about making birthday cakes without eggs, or how the whole neighborhood would share whatever anyone had managed to grow in their garden."

Dr. Morrison nodded thoughtfully, making a brief note on a pad beside her. "That's beautiful, Margaret. You've touched on something crucial—how stories carry wisdom across generations, how they can provide strength in difficult moments. Who else would like to share?"

The young man with paint-stained fingers cleared his throat. "This might sound strange, but there was this old man who used to come into the café where I worked a few years ago. Every morning, same table, same order. But he would tell me these incredible stories about his time as a merchant sailor. Stories about storms that lasted for days, ports in countries I'd never heard of, people he'd met who changed his entire perspective on life. I looked forward to those stories more than anything else about that job. When he died suddenly, I realized I'd learned more about courage and curiosity from his stories than from anything else in my life up to that point."

As more students shared their experiences, Stafford noticed how Dr. Morrison listened to each response with genuine attention, occasionally asking a follow-up question that drew out additional details or helped the speaker articulate why the story had resonated so deeply. She had a gift for making people feel heard, for finding the thread that connected each individual response to larger themes about human nature and experience.

When his turn came, Stafford found himself talking about his grandfather's railway stories, surprised by how easily the words came and how clearly he could articulate why those tales had mattered to him. Dr. Morrison's eyes brightened as he spoke, and she asked him whether he thought those stories had influenced his choice to work with his hands, to find meaning in practical problem-solving.

"I never thought about it that way," Stafford admitted, "but yes, I think they did. My grandfather always talked about work as something noble, regardless of how simple or complex the task might be. There was dignity in doing things properly, in understanding how systems worked and taking responsibility for your part in keeping them running."

"That's a profound insight, Stafford," Dr. Morrison said, and the way she said his name made him feel recognized in a way that went beyond simple politeness. "You've identified something that many great writers have explored—the relationship between meaningful work and personal identity, the satisfaction that comes from mastery and craftsmanship. We'll be looking at several stories this semester that deal with exactly those themes."

As the evening progressed, they discussed the first assigned reading—a collection of short stories by Alice Munro that had initially intimidated Stafford with their subtle complexity. Under Dr. Morrison's guidance, however, the stories began to reveal layers of meaning he hadn't noticed during his initial reading. She had a remarkable ability to ask questions that illuminated character motivations and thematic elements without making anyone feel stupid for having missed them the first time through.

"One of the things I love about Munro's work," Dr. Morrison explained as they discussed a particularly nuanced story about a woman reflecting on her marriage, "is how she captures the way people actually think and remember. Life doesn't unfold in neat chronological order with clear moral lessons. We jump back and forth in time, we contradict ourselves, we discover that events we thought we understood completely look entirely different from new perspectives."

She moved to the whiteboard again and began sketching a simple diagram. "Traditional story structure suggests a clear beginning, middle, and end—rising action, climax, resolution. But Munro and writers like her are more interested in the way real human experience works. The 'climax' might have happened twenty years ago, and the story might be about someone finally understanding what it meant. Or the most important event might be something that seems almost insignificant on the surface—a brief conversation, a moment of recognition, a small choice that changes everything."

Stafford found himself leaning forward, genuinely engaged by this analysis. There was something deeply satisfying about understanding how these stories worked, about recognizing the craft involved in creating seemingly effortless prose that carried such emotional weight. It reminded him of the satisfaction he felt when he successfully diagnosed a complex electrical problem—that moment when all the pieces fell into place and revealed the elegant logic underlying apparent confusion.

As the class session drew to a close, Dr. Morrison distributed the reading assignment for the following week—several short stories by different authors, along with a brief essay about the role of conflict in narrative. "I want you to pay attention not just to what happens in these stories, but to how the authors reveal information, how they use dialogue and description to create mood and atmosphere. Don't worry about getting everything right—we'll discuss it all together next week."

Students began gathering their belongings and filtering out of the classroom, many lingering to chat with classmates or ask Dr. Morrison additional questions about the assignment. Stafford packed his notebook slowly, reluctant to end the evening. He couldn't remember the last time two hours had passed so quickly, or when he had felt so intellectually stimulated.

As he approached the door, Dr. Morrison called his name softly. "Stafford, could I speak with you for a moment?"

He paused, wondering if he had said something inappropriate during the discussion or if she had concerns about his ability to keep up with the coursework. But her expression was warm and encouraging as she approached him.

"I wanted to tell you how much I enjoyed your contributions tonight," she said, gathering her papers into her leather satchel. "You have a very thoughtful way of connecting literature to real experience. It's exactly the kind of perspective that makes these discussions richer for everyone."**Chapter 2**

The drive home from the learning center took Stafford through the quiet streets of central Geelong, past the familiar landmarks that had defined his adult life—the pub where he occasionally met Jim and the other electricians for after-work drinks, the hardware store where he had an account and knew every staff member by name, the small apartment building where he rented a one-bedroom unit that had served his simple needs for the past six years. Tonight, however, these familiar sights seemed somehow different, as if Dr. Morrison's words about perspective and understanding had shifted the lens through which he viewed his own world.

Her brief comment after class had stayed with him during the twenty-minute drive, not because it was particularly profound or surprising, but because of the genuine warmth with which she had delivered it. In his years of working with customers and colleagues, Stafford had become adept at distinguishing between polite pleasantries and authentic engagement. Dr. Morrison's appreciation had felt real, unforced, as if she truly valued the connections he had drawn between the literature and his own experience.

Back in his apartment, Stafford made himself a cup of tea and settled into his reading chair—a secondhand leather recliner that was beginning to show its age but remained supremely comfortable—with the stories assigned for the following week. The first was by a writer named Raymond Carver, whose spare, understated prose initially struck him as almost too simple. The story concerned a baker who makes angry phone calls to a family whose child has been injured in an accident, not knowing about the crisis they are facing. On the surface, it seemed like a straightforward tale about miscommunication and eventual understanding, but as Stafford read more carefully, he began to notice the layers of meaning that Dr. Morrison had taught them to look for.

The way Carver revealed information gradually, allowing readers to understand the baker's motivation at the same pace as the characters themselves, reminded Stafford of troubleshooting an electrical problem. You started with obvious possibilities and worked your way through increasingly subtle explanations until you found the root cause of the malfunction. Both processes required patience, methodical thinking, and the willingness to look beyond surface appearances to understand underlying systems and connections.

As he continued reading, Stafford found himself making notes in the margins—something he had never done with a work of literature before, but which felt natural after watching Dr. Morrison demonstrate close reading techniques. He noted places where Carver used dialogue to reveal character, moments when seemingly insignificant details carried emotional weight, instances where the author's careful word choices created specific moods or atmospheres. The process felt surprisingly similar to the way he analyzed wiring diagrams, looking for patterns and relationships that might not be immediately obvious but which were crucial to understanding how the whole system functioned.

The following morning at work, Stafford found himself thinking about the stories even as he focused on replacing the electrical panel in a renovated Victorian home on Eastern Beach Road. Jim noticed his unusually contemplative mood during their coffee break, settling his substantial frame into a folding chair in the back of their work van while they ate sandwiches and watched seagulls scavenge for scraps in the nearby park.

"You're quiet today," Jim observed, unwrapping what appeared to be his wife's famous corned beef sandwich. "Everything alright? You didn't seem like yourself yesterday afternoon either. Not complaining about your work, mind you—you're still the most thorough electrician I've got working for me. But you've got that distant look again, like your mind is somewhere else entirely."

Stafford considered how much to reveal about his evening classes, uncertain whether Jim would view his literary pursuits as a positive development or as evidence that he was losing focus on his electrical career. In the hierarchical world of trades work, intellectual interests were sometimes viewed with suspicion, as if thinking too much about abstract concepts might somehow compromise one's ability to work effectively with concrete problems and practical solutions.

"I've been taking an evening class," he said finally, deciding that honesty was preferable to evasion. "Literature course at the community learning center. It's got me thinking about things differently, I suppose. How people communicate, how they understand each other, why some conversations work and others don't."

Jim raised his eyebrows but didn't seem particularly surprised by this revelation. "Literature, eh? Like Shakespeare and all that? Never had much use for poetry myself, but my wife loves those romance novels. Reads them constantly, tells me all about the characters like they're real people she knows personally." He took a substantial bite of his sandwich and chewed thoughtfully. "What kind of stuff are you reading?"

"Short stories, mostly. Contemporary writers who write about ordinary people dealing with everyday problems. The instructor—Dr. Morrison—she's got this way of helping you see how much is really going on beneath the surface of what seems like simple situations. It's actually quite fascinating, the way writers can pack so much meaning into just a few pages of text."

"Dr. Morrison, is it?" Jim's tone carried a hint of something that might have been amusement. "And what's this doctor like? Old professor type with thick glasses and a beard, I'm guessing? Most of the literature teachers I remember from school were either ancient or completely mad, sometimes both."

Stafford felt an unexpected warmth rise in his cheeks and hoped Jim wouldn't notice his slight embarrassment. "Actually, she's probably younger than either of us. Very intelligent, obviously, but she has this gift for making complicated ideas accessible. She doesn't talk down to anyone or make them feel stupid for not understanding something immediately. The whole class feels more like a conversation than a lecture."

Jim nodded slowly, his expression suggesting that he was reading more into Stafford's description than had been explicitly stated. "Sounds like you're enjoying it, anyway. That's good—man needs interests outside of work, keeps the mind sharp. My wife's always after me to take up crossword puzzles or learn to play chess, claims it'll prevent dementia or some such thing. Maybe there's something to be said for exercising the brain as well as the hands."

The conversation moved on to practical matters—their schedule for the remainder of the week, a complex rewiring job that would require careful planning and coordination with other tradespeople, Jim's ongoing concerns about finding qualified apprentices who were willing to learn the trade properly rather than cutting corners to finish jobs quickly. But Stafford noticed that Jim seemed to be observing him more carefully than usual, as if trying to assess whether his newfound intellectual pursuits were likely to affect his commitment to electrical work.

That evening's class focused on the Carver story Stafford had read the night before, and the discussion proved even more engaging than the previous week's session. Dr. Morrison began by asking students to identify the central conflict in the story, and was pleased when several people recognized that the real tension wasn't between the baker and the family, but within each character as they struggled with loneliness, grief, and the difficulty of connecting authentically with other people.

"Carver is often described as a minimalist writer," Dr. Morrison explained, moving around the classroom as she spoke, her energy and enthusiasm making the small space feel dynamic rather than confined. "But I think that term can be misleading. His prose is spare and economical, certainly, but every word carries weight. He's not leaving things out because he's lazy or because he doesn't understand complexity. He's trusting his readers to fill in the emotional and psychological details, to bring their own experiences to bear on understanding what his characters are feeling."

She paused beside the whiteboard and wrote a brief quote from the story: "They talked on into the early morning, the high, pale cast of light in the windows, and they did not think of leaving." Then she turned back to face the class. "This is the final sentence of the story. On one level, it's simply describing what happened—three people stayed up all night talking. But what else is Carver telling us with this sentence?"

Margaret, the nurse who had spoken so eloquently about her grandmother's stories, raised her hand tentatively. "It feels like they've found something they didn't know they were looking for. The baker was angry and the parents were grieving, but by the end they've connected with each other in a way that none of them expected. The fact that they don't want to leave suggests that the conversation has become something precious, something that's helping heal all of them."

"Exactly right, Margaret. And notice how Carver achieves this effect—he doesn't tell us directly that the characters have found comfort and connection. He shows us through their behavior, through their reluctance to end the conversation. As readers, we have to infer the emotional transformation that has taken place."

Stafford found himself raising his hand, still slightly self-conscious about participating but increasingly engaged by the discussion. "It reminds me of the way people behave after they've worked together to solve a difficult problem. You've seen it on job sites when multiple trades have to coordinate to deal with some unexpected complication—plumbers, electricians, carpenters all trying to figure out how to make everything work together. When you finally find the solution, nobody wants to leave immediately. There's this sense of shared accomplishment, of having understood something together that none of you could have figured out individually."

Dr. Morrison's face lit up with genuine delight at this comparison. "That's a brilliant observation, Stafford. You've identified something really important about how human connection works—it's often forged through shared struggle or shared discovery rather than through simple social pleasantries. Carver understands that people often reveal their deepest selves not in moments of happiness, but in moments of crisis when their usual defenses are down."

As the discussion continued, Stafford noticed that he was becoming more comfortable expressing his thoughts, more confident in his ability to contribute meaningfully to the literary analysis. The connections between the stories and his own experiences seemed to come naturally, and he found that his practical background often provided a unique perspective that complemented the more traditional academic approaches of some of his classmates.

During the break, while other students stepped outside for fresh air or visited the restroom, Stafford remained in his seat, reviewing his notes from the evening's discussion. Dr. Morrison approached his desk, carrying two cups of tea from the small kitchenette down the hall.

"I thought you might like some tea," she said, offering him one of the cups. "I noticed you seemed to be concentrating quite intensely tonight. I hope the material isn't becoming overwhelming—sometimes adult learners worry that they need to absorb everything immediately, but literary analysis is really a skill that develops gradually with practice."

Stafford accepted the tea gratefully, surprised by the gesture and by her attentiveness to his learning process. "Actually, I'm finding it easier than I expected. Not easy, exactly, but... satisfying, I suppose. There's something appealing about the way these stories work, the way authors can say so much with so little. It reminds me of elegant engineering—achieving maximum effect with minimum waste."

Dr. Morrison settled into the desk next to his, cradling her own cup of tea between her hands. "That's a fascinating way to think about it. I've never heard anyone compare literary technique to engineering principles, but there's real wisdom in that comparison. The best writers, like the best engineers, understand their materials thoroughly and use them with precision and economy."

She paused, studying his face with an expression that seemed to blend professional interest with personal curiosity. "Can I ask what drew you to this particular class? We get students with all sorts of backgrounds and motivations, but you seem to have a natural instinct for textual analysis that suggests you might have been thinking about these kinds of questions for longer than you realized."

The directness of her question, combined with her obvious genuine interest in his response, created a moment of intimacy that caught Stafford slightly off guard. He found himself wanting to give her an honest answer, to explain the restlessness and dissatisfaction that had been growing in his professional life, the sense that his skills had plateaued and his passion for electrical work had diminished.

"I've been feeling stuck lately," he said, surprised by his own candor. "Not unhappy, exactly, but... limited, I suppose. Like I was using only a small part of my mind, even though I'm good at what I do and I find satisfaction in solving practical problems. I thought maybe expanding into something completely different might help me understand what was missing."

Dr. Morrison nodded thoughtfully, her dark eyes reflecting genuine understanding rather than merely polite interest. "That makes perfect sense. Many people find that engaging with literature changes the way they think about everything else in their lives—their work, their relationships, their understanding of themselves. Stories have this remarkable ability to expand our empathy and imagination, to help us see familiar situations from entirely new perspectives."

She glanced around the classroom, where other students were beginning to return from their break, then back at Stafford with a slight smile that seemed to acknowledge the special nature of their conversation. "I hope you'll continue to trust those instincts that brought you here. You have a gift for finding unexpected connections between literature and experience, and that kind of thinking enriches everyone's understanding."

As the second half of the class began and they moved on to discussing the next assigned story, Stafford found himself acutely aware of Dr. Morrison's presence in a way that went beyond simple appreciation for her teaching abilities. The way she gestured when making a point, the careful attention she paid to each student's contributions, the obvious passion she felt for literature and for helping others discover its rewards—all of these qualities combined to create an impression of someone who was not only intellectually gifted but also deeply committed to meaningful human connection.

When the class ended and students began gathering their belongings, Stafford lingered again, ostensibly organizing his notes but actually hoping for another brief conversation with Dr. Morrison. She seemed to sense his desire to talk and approached his desk as the last of the other students filed out of the classroom.

"How are you finding the reading load so far?" she asked, beginning to erase the whiteboard while they talked. "I know it can be challenging to fit academic work into an already busy schedule, especially when you're not used to the particular demands of literary analysis."

"It's manageable," Stafford replied, though he realized as he said it that 'manageable' didn't adequately describe his experience. "Actually, it's more than that. I find myself thinking about the stories even when I'm not actively reading or preparing for class. They seem to stick with me in ways that surprised me."

Dr. Morrison paused in her erasing and turned to face him fully, her expression suggesting that his response had pleased her considerably. "That's exactly what should happen when literature is working properly. The best stories don't end when you finish reading them—they continue to resonate, to raise new questions, to cast new light on experiences you thought you already understood completely."

She moved to her desk and began packing her materials into her leather satchel, but continued the conversation as she worked. "I've been teaching literature for almost ten years now, and I still get excited when I see students making those deeper connections. It's one of the most rewarding aspects of this work—watching people discover that they're capable of more sophisticated thinking than they previously realized."

Stafford found himself reluctant to end the conversation and leave the classroom, much like the characters in the Carver story who had been unwilling to conclude their unexpected night of meaningful dialogue. There was something about Dr. Morrison's combination of intellectual rigor and genuine warmth that made him feel both challenged and supported, as if she saw potential in him that he was only beginning to recognize in himself.

"I should let you get home," he said finally, standing and gathering his own materials. "Thank you for the tea, and for... well, for making this such an interesting experience. I wasn't entirely sure what I was getting myself into when I enrolled, but it's turning out to be exactly what I needed, even though I couldn't have articulated what that was at the time."

Dr. Morrison smiled, shouldering her satchel and moving toward the light switches by the classroom door. "I'm so glad to hear that, Stafford. Learning should feel like discovery, like adventure. When it becomes mere routine or obligation, we've lost something essential about what makes us human."

As they walked together toward the building's main entrance, their footsteps echoing in the quiet hallways of the learning center, Stafford found himself hoping that the semester would pass slowly, that these Tuesday evening conversations about literature and life would continue to provide the intellectual stimulation and human connection that had been missing from his daily routine. For the first time in months, he felt genuinely excited about something beyond the immediate demands of his work, and that excitement seemed to be awakening other possibilities he hadn't previously considered.**Chapter 3**

The following weeks settled into a rhythm that brought Stafford a satisfaction he hadn't experienced in years. His Tuesday and Thursday evenings were anchored by Dr. Morrison's literature class, but he found that the intellectual curiosity awakened by those sessions began to permeate other aspects of his life. He started carrying a small notebook in his work van, jotting down observations about the people he encountered during service calls—the way an elderly man's hands shook slightly as he described the flickering lights in his kitchen, suggesting anxiety that went beyond simple concern about electrical problems, or how a young mother's careful questions about child safety revealed depths of protective love that reminded him of characters in the stories they had been reading.

At work, Jim continued to observe these changes with a mixture of amusement and curiosity. Stafford had always been thorough and professional, but lately he seemed more engaged with the human elements of their job—taking extra time to explain electrical systems to customers, asking follow-up questions about how problems had developed, showing genuine interest in the stories behind the service calls they received. During one particularly complex rewiring job at a heritage-listed building in central Geelong, Jim commented on how Stafford had spent nearly twenty minutes discussing the building's history with the property manager, learning about previous renovations and the challenges of maintaining modern electrical standards in a structure that had been built more than a century ago.

"You've always been good with customers," Jim said as they loaded their tools back into the van after completing the installation, "but lately it's like you're seeing them as whole people instead of just problems to be solved. Not complaining, mind you—that property manager was so impressed with your professionalism that he mentioned recommending us for three other heritage projects his company is managing. Just interesting to watch you develop this way."

Stafford considered Jim's observation as they drove to their next appointment, recognizing the truth in his supervisor's assessment. The literature class had indeed changed the way he approached human interactions, making him more attentive to the stories people told about themselves and more curious about the experiences that shaped their perspectives. Dr. Morrison had talked extensively about how great writers developed empathy for their characters, how they learned to see the world through different eyes and understand motivations that might initially seem foreign or incomprehensible. Without consciously deciding to do so, Stafford had begun applying these same principles to his daily encounters with customers and colleagues.

The reading assignments continued to challenge and reward his attention. They had moved from contemporary short stories to excerpts from classic novels, and Stafford was surprised to discover how accessible writers like Jane Austen and Charles Dickens could be when approached with proper guidance. Dr. Morrison had a remarkable talent for helping students understand historical and cultural contexts without getting bogged down in academic jargon or abstract theoretical frameworks. She focused consistently on character development, narrative technique, and thematic content that connected to universal human experiences rather than requiring specialized knowledge of literary criticism or biographical details about the authors.

During one particularly memorable class session, they discussed a passage from Dickens's "Great Expectations" in which the protagonist, Pip, reflects on how his expectations and assumptions about social class had blinded him to the genuine worth of people he had known since childhood. Dr. Morrison asked the class to consider how the passage might relate to their own experiences of misjudging people or situations based on surface appearances or preconceived notions.

Margaret, the nurse, spoke about how she had initially been intimidated by a colleague who seemed cold and unfriendly, only to discover that the woman was struggling with her mother's declining health and was simply trying to maintain professional composure during an emotionally difficult period. The young artist, whose name Stafford had learned was David, shared a story about dismissing a gallery owner as pretentious and out of touch, then later realizing that the man was genuinely trying to help emerging artists navigate the commercial aspects of the art world, drawing from his own experiences of financial struggle and artistic compromise.

When Dr. Morrison's attention turned to him, Stafford found himself thinking about his relationship with his parents, who had never quite understood his decision to pursue electrical work instead of university education. For years, he had interpreted their periodic questions about his career satisfaction and future plans as criticism or disappointment, evidence that they viewed his chosen profession as somehow beneath his potential. But recently, influenced by the psychological complexity he had been learning to recognize in literary characters, he had begun to wonder whether their questions might actually reflect concern and love rather than judgment—a desire to ensure that he was finding fulfillment and using his capabilities fully, even if they couldn't understand the specific satisfactions of skilled trades work.

"I think I've been misinterpreting my parents' attitudes toward my career for years," he said, articulating these thoughts for the first time. "They always seemed disapproving when they asked about work or suggested I might want to consider other opportunities. But maybe they were just trying to understand something outside their own experience, trying to make sure I was happy even though they couldn't relate to what made electrical work satisfying for me."

Dr. Morrison nodded encouragingly, clearly pleased by the depth of his reflection. "That's exactly the kind of insight that literature can provide, Staffford. When we learn to look beyond surface behaviors and consider the complex motivations that drive human actions, we often discover that situations we thought we understood completely are actually much more nuanced and complicated. The morning sun filtered through the dusty workshop windows of Geelong Electric Services, casting long shadows across the concrete floor where Stafford McKenzie crouched, his weathered hands working methodically through a tangle of copper wiring. At thirty-two, he had spent nearly half his life learning the language of electricity—understanding how current flows, where resistance builds, and why circuits sometimes fail without warning. There was something almost poetic about it, he thought, the way power moved invisibly through walls and brought life to dead spaces.

His apprenticeship had begun when he was barely seventeen, eager to escape the suffocating expectations of university that his parents had pressed upon him. While his classmates pursued degrees in business and engineering, Stafford found solace in the honest work of his hands. The smell of heated wire, the satisfying snap of a properly installed breaker, the gentle hum of a well-wired panel—these became the soundtrack of his adult life.

But lately, something had been missing. Perhaps it was the repetitive nature of residential work, or maybe the growing sense that his skills had plateaued. His supervisor, Jim Hartwell, a gruff man in his sixties who had been rewiring Geelong homes since the seventies, noticed Stafford's restlessness during their coffee breaks.

"You're getting that look again," Jim observed one Tuesday morning, stirring sugar into his instant coffee with a plastic spoon. "Same look my youngest had before he decided to become a bloody chef instead of taking over the family business."

Stafford glanced up from his work order, pen hovering over the clipboard. "What look?"

"Like you're somewhere else entirely. Like this—" Jim gestured around the cramped office with its peeling linoleum and fluorescent lights "—isn't enough anymore."

The comment stung because it carried truth. Stafford had been feeling increasingly disconnected from his work, going through the motions without the passion that once drove him to master every aspect of electrical installation. He completed jobs efficiently, customers praised his professionalism, but the spark—if he could forgive himself the pun—had dimmed considerably.

That afternoon, while replacing a faulty outlet in a weatherboard house on Aberdeen Street, Stafford found himself thinking about Jim's words. The homeowner, an elderly woman named Mrs. Chen, brought him tea and biscuits, chatting about her late husband who had also worked with his hands as a carpenter. She spoke with such warmth about how he had found joy in creating something beautiful and functional from raw materials.

"He used to say that every piece of wood had a story to tell," Mrs. Chen explained, settling into her favorite armchair while Stafford tested the new outlet. "You just had to listen carefully enough to hear it."

As he packed his tools and prepared to leave, Mrs. Chen handed him a small card. "My neighbor mentioned you might be interested in expanding your skills. There's an adult education center downtown that offers evening classes. All sorts of subjects—literature, history, even some technical courses that might complement your electrical work."

Stafford accepted the card politely, expecting to forget about it before he reached his van. But something about the woman's genuine concern, combined with his growing dissatisfaction, made him slip the card into his wallet instead of the trash.

The Geelong Community Learning Center occupied a converted Victorian mansion on Moorabool Street, its red brick facade softened by climbing ivy and the warm glow of windows that promised knowledge and possibility. Three days after his encounter with Mrs. Chen, Stafford found himself climbing the front steps, drawn by curiosity and a vague hope that perhaps expanding his mind might rekindle his passion for his craft.

The reception area buzzed with activity—students of all ages consulting bulletin boards, elderly couples discussing pottery classes, young mothers juggling toddlers while inquiring about computer courses. Stafford felt simultaneously out of place and oddly at home among these seekers of knowledge.

A cheerful woman behind the information desk handed him a course catalog thick with possibilities. "First time here? Wonderful! We have classes starting next week in everything from basic accounting to creative writing. What sort of thing interests you?"

Stafford flipped through the pages, his eyes scanning course descriptions that ranged from practical to purely intellectual. Automotive maintenance, small business management, photography, philosophy—the variety was overwhelming. Then, near the back of the catalog, he found something that made him pause: "Literature and Life: How Great Books Shape Our Understanding of the World."

The course description was modest but intriguing: "An exploration of classic and contemporary literature, designed for adult learners who want to discover how storytelling reflects and influences human experience. No previous English literature background required. Evening sessions accommodate working adults."

Something about the phrasing appealed to him. He had always been a reader, though his tastes ran more toward technical manuals and thriller novels than what might be considered serious literature. But the idea of understanding how stories worked, how writers managed to capture complex emotions and experiences in words, held unexpected appeal.

The woman at the desk noticed his interest. "That's one of our most popular courses. Dr. Morrison is an exceptional instructor—really knows how to make literature accessible without dumbing it down. The class is quite diverse, too. We've had everyone from retired teachers to trades people to busy parents."

Stafford found himself nodding, though he hadn't consciously made a decision. "How do I enroll?"

Twenty minutes later, he walked back to his van with a receipt for his first literature course, wondering what impulse had led him to commit to spending two evenings a week discussing books with strangers. The rational part of his mind questioned whether he would have time for homework and reading assignments on top of his regular work schedule. But a deeper part of him, the part that had been growing increasingly restless, felt genuinely excited for the first time in months.

The following Tuesday evening, Stafford arrived at the learning center fifteen minutes early, carrying a notebook and the course's first assigned reading—a collection of short stories that he had managed to work through over the weekend. The classroom was smaller than he had expected, arranged with desks in a rough circle rather than traditional rows. Slowly, other students filtered in: a woman in her fifties wearing scrubs who he guessed was a nurse, a young man with paint-stained fingers who might have been an artist, several people around his own age whose professions were less obvious.

At exactly seven o'clock, the instructor entered, and Stafford felt his carefully managed expectations shift dramatically.

Dr. Elizabeth Morrison was perhaps thirty-five, with dark hair pulled back in a practical ponytail and intelligent eyes that seemed to take in everything at once. She wore a simple blue dress and carried a leather satchel that looked well-used and well-loved. But it wasn't her appearance that caught Stafford off-guard—it was the way she moved through the space, the quiet confidence with which she arranged her materials, the genuine smile she offered to each student as she made eye contact around the room.

"Good evening, everyone," Dr. Morrison said, her voice carrying easily through the small classroom without seeming forced or theatrical. "I know some of you might be wondering what you've gotten yourselves into, especially if it's been a while since you've been in a classroom setting. I want to start by assuring you that this isn't going to be like any English class you might remember from school. We're not here to dissect literature until it's lifeless, or to hunt for hidden meanings that may or may not exist. We're here to explore how stories work, why they matter, and what they can teach us about being human."

She moved to the whiteboard and wrote a single question in neat handwriting: "What is a story?" Then she turned back to face the class, leaning against her desk with an expression that invited participation rather than demanded it. "I'd like to hear from each of you—just briefly—about a story that has stayed with you. It doesn't have to be from a book. It could be something someone told you, a family legend, even something you experienced yourself. What made it memorable?"

The silence that followed wasn't uncomfortable, but rather expectant. Stafford found himself thinking not about books he had read, but about the stories his grandfather used to tell about working on the railways, tales filled with larger-than-life characters and near-disasters avoided through quick thinking and teamwork. Those stories had shaped his understanding of honest work and the dignity that came from doing a job well, even when nobody was watching.

The woman in scrubs spoke first, her voice soft but clear. "My grandmother used to tell me stories about growing up during the Depression. They weren't particularly dramatic stories—mostly about making do with very little, finding ways to celebrate small victories. But they taught me more about resilience than any self-help book ever could. Even now, when I'm having a difficult day at the hospital, I remember her stories about making birthday cakes without eggs, or how the whole neighborhood would share whatever anyone had managed to grow in their garden."

Dr. Morrison nodded thoughtfully, making a brief note on a pad beside her. "That's beautiful, Margaret. You've touched on something crucial—how stories carry wisdom across generations, how they can provide strength in difficult moments. Who else would like to share?"

The young man with paint-stained fingers cleared his throat. "This might sound strange, but there was this old man who used to come into the café where I worked a few years ago. Every morning, same table, same order. But he would tell me these incredible stories about his time as a merchant sailor. Stories about storms that lasted for days, ports in countries I'd never heard of, people he'd met who changed his entire perspective on life. I looked forward to those stories more than anything else about that job. When he died suddenly, I realized I'd learned more about courage and curiosity from his stories than from anything else in my life up to that point."

As more students shared their experiences, Stafford noticed how Dr. Morrison listened to each response with genuine attention, occasionally asking a follow-up question that drew out additional details or helped the speaker articulate why the story had resonated so deeply. She had a gift for making people feel heard, for finding the thread that connected each individual response to larger themes about human nature and experience.

When his turn came, Stafford found himself talking about his grandfather's railway stories, surprised by how easily the words came and how clearly he could articulate why those tales had mattered to him. Dr. Morrison's eyes brightened as he spoke, and she asked him whether he thought those stories had influenced his choice to work with his hands, to find meaning in practical problem-solving.

"I never thought about it that way," Stafford admitted, "but yes, I think they did. My grandfather always talked about work as something noble, regardless of how simple or complex the task might be. There was dignity in doing things properly, in understanding how systems worked and taking responsibility for your part in keeping them running."

"That's a profound insight, Stafford," Dr. Morrison said, and the way she said his name made him feel recognized in a way that went beyond simple politeness. "You've identified something that many great writers have explored—the relationship between meaningful work and personal identity, the satisfaction that comes from mastery and craftsmanship. We'll be looking at several stories this semester that deal with exactly those themes."

As the evening progressed, they discussed the first assigned reading—a collection of short stories by Alice Munro that had initially intimidated Stafford with their subtle complexity. Under Dr. Morrison's guidance, however, the stories began to reveal layers of meaning he hadn't noticed during his initial reading. She had a remarkable ability to ask questions that illuminated character motivations and thematic elements without making anyone feel stupid for having missed them the first time through.

"One of the things I love about Munro's work," Dr. Morrison explained as they discussed a particularly nuanced story about a woman reflecting on her marriage, "is how she captures the way people actually think and remember. Life doesn't unfold in neat chronological order with clear moral lessons. We jump back and forth in time, we contradict ourselves, we discover that events we thought we understood completely look entirely different from new perspectives."

She moved to the whiteboard again and began sketching a simple diagram. "Traditional story structure suggests a clear beginning, middle, and end—rising action, climax, resolution. But Munro and writers like her are more interested in the way real human experience works. The 'climax' might have happened twenty years ago, and the story might be about someone finally understanding what it meant. Or the most important event might be something that seems almost insignificant on the surface—a brief conversation, a moment of recognition, a small choice that changes everything."

Stafford found himself leaning forward, genuinely engaged by this analysis. There was something deeply satisfying about understanding how these stories worked, about recognizing the craft involved in creating seemingly effortless prose that carried such emotional weight. It reminded him of the satisfaction he felt when he successfully diagnosed a complex electrical problem—that moment when all the pieces fell into place and revealed the elegant logic underlying apparent confusion.

As the class session drew to a close, Dr. Morrison distributed the reading assignment for the following week—several short stories by different authors, along with a brief essay about the role of conflict in narrative. "I want you to pay attention not just to what happens in these stories, but to how the authors reveal information, how they use dialogue and description to create mood and atmosphere. Don't worry about getting everything right—we'll discuss it all together next week."

Students began gathering their belongings and filtering out of the classroom, many lingering to chat with classmates or ask Dr. Morrison additional questions about the assignment. Stafford packed his notebook slowly, reluctant to end the evening. He couldn't remember the last time two hours had passed so quickly, or when he had felt so intellectually stimulated.

As he approached the door, Dr. Morrison called his name softly. "Stafford, could I speak with you for a moment?"

He paused, wondering if he had said something inappropriate during the discussion or if she had concerns about his ability to keep up with the coursework. But her expression was warm and encouraging as she approached him.
